Alan,
I had the same thought.  I don't see why o-suriage would be more challenging to fit than a newly made sword.  But, I've never made a habaki.

I had a sword with an old-looking, somewhat crude two piece plain copper habaki.  It was on a sword that was shortened a few cm.  It served its purpose, but it was far from precision work.  
Jim



  Jim,
  If anything it would be easier to fit a habaki to an o-suriage blade than an
  ubu one as the latter might have a nakago that is greatly thicker than the
  blade itself.

  I have a two piece habaki that is solid gold/silver covered with sheet gold,
  it looks very old and is of crude manufacture compared with similar good
  quality late Edo habaki which fit together almost like clockwork. I think it
  was probably made by a country maker, any thoughts on this would be welcome.
  Alan
